Welcome to the Ready for R! Workshop Series organised by the Research Training Unit, Faculty of Medicine, Universiti Malaya, Malaysia


This workshop lays the groundwork for addressing key practical aspects of programming and other essential computer skills needed for both research and implementation of statistical methods in three parts. In its first section, the workshop will introduce participants to programming in R and the tidyverse, guidance on coding best practices, and a primer on data wrangling. The second section will explore data visualization, as well as an exploration of both descriptive and inferential statistics using R. The final section of the workshop introduces the concept of regression analysis in R.



Have a look at the schedule below and download the necessary .qmd files for each session. While I have included solutions- it would be way more beneficial to attempt these yourself first. Lets try to maximise learning in the three sessions.
If you are new to R, don’t worry - start off with this deck to learn how to install the software and familiarise yourself with the environment.

title: Introduction to R
text:
Data Structures

Exercise 1: Creating a Data Frame

Create a data frame named ‘employees’ with columns ‘name’, ‘salary’, and ‘department’
Print the summary of the data frame.



Show the solution
employees <- data.frame(name = c("Alice", "Bob"), salary = c(50000, 60000), department = c("HR", "Finance"))
summary(employees)




Exercise 2: Accessing Elements in a Matrix

Create a matrix ‘mat’ with the numbers 1 to 12 and 3 rows
Print the element in the first row and second column.



Show the solution
mat <- matrix(c(1:12), nrow = 3)
print(mat[1, 2]) # Output will be 4





Basic Data Manipulation

Exercise 1: Subsetting Data

Create a data frame ‘products’ with columns ‘ProductID’, ‘Price’
Print the filtered data.



Show the solution
products <- data.frame(ProductID = c(1, 2, 3), Price = c(15, 25, 30))
print(products)




Exercise 2: Setting and Getting Working Directory

Determine your current working directory.
Set a new working directory to a folder of your choice (e.g., “C:/my_folder”).
Verify that the working directory has been changed by getting the current working directory again.



Show the solution
# Get the current working directory
getwd()

# Set a new working directory
setwd("C:/my_folder")

# Verify the working directory has been changed
getwd() # Output will be "C:/my_folder"





Exercise 3: Calling in Data Using readxl

Install and load the readxl package
Download the quarantine.xlsx file from here and place it in you working directory
Use the read_excel function to read an Excel file (e.g., “quarantine.xlsx”) from your working directory.



Show the solution
# Install the readxl package (if not already installed)
install.packages("readxl")

# Load the readxl package
library(readxl)

# Read the Excel file
data <- read_excel("quarantine.xlsx")




Exercise 4: Using Basic Functions

Print the first 6 rows of the sample data
Print the summary of the ‘lattitude’ column.



Show the solution
data(data)
head(data)
summary(data$lattitude)
